questions.text: EcoRI is a restriction endonuclease used to cut the human DNA before inserting it into a plasmid. Which of the following is the recognition sequence for this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Certain endonuclease enzymes that cut DNA at specific DNA sequences within the molecule are a key tool in recombinant DNA research. These enzymes were termed restriction enzymes, or Res.
  • Restriction enzymes cut the DNA of any source into unique, short pieces in a sequence-specific manner, in contrast to most other enzymatic, chemical, or physical methods, which break DNA randomly.
  • Restriction enzymes are named after the bacterium from which they are isolated.
  • For example, EcoRI is from Escherichia coli,

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionised genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - associated gene 9)

  • CRISPR is a gene editing and regulatory technique. (Option A)
  • Found in prokaryotes (bacteria and archaea), derived from bacteriophage DNA.
  • Acts as an antiviral defense system, helping prokaryotes detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages.
  • Provides adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection by specific phages.
  • Complements restriction endonucleases and methylases.
  • RNA-based targeting guides the Cas9 nuclease to complementary DNA for editing.

CAS9: CRISPR-associated protein 9

  • An endonuclease enzyme. (Option C)
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA). (Option B)
  • Then recognises specific DNA strands that are complementary to the CRISPR sequence & cleaves them.

CRISPR CAS9

  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms.
  • Within bacteria, this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

Applications of CRISPR in Eukaryotes:

  • CRISPR has been adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including humans, functioning as an RNA-guided site-specific nuclease.
  • It has broad applications in:
    • Medicine - used experimentally for genetic disorders (e.g., sickle cell disease) and viral infections like HIV.
    • Basic research - enables gene deletion, editing, visualization, and transcription modulation.
    • Agriculture & food industry - applied for genetic improvements.
  • CRISPR is a highly specific and efficient tool for DNA manipulation and genetic analysis in mammalian cells.
  • A variant, C2c2, can site-specifically cleave RNA, offering the potential to alter mRNA levels in human cells.

questions.text: In addition to Taq polymerases, PCR requires all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primase is not used in PCR.

The Polymerase Chain Reaction Method

  • PCR is a technique to amplify specific DNA sequences.
  • It is highly sensitive, selective, and rapid.
  • Specificity comes from two oligonucleotide primers that bind to complementary sequences flanking the target DNA.

Steps in PCR:

  1. Denaturation
    • DNA is heated (>90°C) to separate strands.
  2. Annealing
    • Primers bind to complementary sequences (50-75°C).
  3. Extension
    • DNA polymerase synthesizes new strands from the primers using dNTPs.
  • Each cycle doubles the amount of target DNA → exponential amplification.
  • Thermostable DNA polymerase (from thermophilic bacteria) is used to withstand high temperatures.
  • Typical amplification:
    • 20 cycles → ~106-fold
    • 30 cycles → ~106-fold
  • DNA fragments of 50 bp to 10 kb can be amplified.
  • Each cycle takes ≤ 5-10 minutes.
  • Conditions vary by target and require empirical optimization.

Applications of PCR:

  • DNA/RNA sequencing platforms
  • Forensic analysis from single cells (e.g., sperm, hair follicle)
  • Detection of infectious agents (e.g., latent viruses)
  • Prenatal genetic diagnosis
  • Detection of polymorphisms (SNPs, indels, gene amplifications)
  • Tissue typing for organ transplants
  • Evolutionary studies using ancient DNA
  • Quantitative RNA analysis (via RT-PCR using reverse transcriptase)
  • ChIP assays for studying protein-DNA interactions

Template DNA (Option A) is used as a target DNA to amplify specific sequences.

All four Deoxyribonucleotide triphosphates (Option B) are used in PCR, which are polymerized by DNA polymerase.

Primers (Option C) that hybridize to complementary sequences on opposite strands of DNA and flank the target sequence.

questions.text: Many genetic diseases and viral infections are diagnosed on the basis of PCR. Specificity of PCR is based on the use of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • PCR is a method of amplifying a target sequence of DNA.
  • The development of PCR has revolutionized the ways in which both DNA and RNA can be studied.
  • PCR provides a sensitive, selective, and extremely rapid means of amplifying any desired sequence of DNA.
  • Specificity is based on the use of two oligonucleotide primers that hybridize to complementary sequences on opposite strands of DNA and flank the target sequence.

Taq DNA Polymerase enzyme (Option A): DNA synthesis is catalysed by a heat-stable DNA polymerase purified from one of a number of different thermophilic bacteria, organisms that grow at 70 to 80°C. Specificity is based on the use of two oligonucleotide primers that hybridise to complementary sequences on opposite strands of DNA and flank the target sequence.

Deoxyribonucleotide (Option C): All four Deoxyribonucleotides are used in PCR, which are polymerised by DNA polymerase.

Temperature (Option D): The DNA sample is first heat-denatured (>90°C) to separate the two strands of the template DNA containing the target sequence.

choices.text: Size and quantify specific RNA molecules
Size and quantify specific protein molecules

questions.text: The overlay blot technique is used to detect:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Overlay blot examines protein-protein interactions.

  • In this technique, proteins are separated by electrophoresis, blotted to a membrane, renatured, and analysed for an interaction with a protein by incubation with a specific labelled protein probe (overlay assay) using either a labelled protein or, alternatively, protein-protein interactions are detected using a specific antibody.

Blotting & Probing Techniques Allow Visualisation of Specific Target Molecules

  • Visualisation of a specific DNA or RNA fragment or protein among the many thousands of contaminating non-target molecules in a complex sample requires the convergence of a number of techniques, collectively termed blot transfer.
  • The first technique is named for the person who devised the technique, Edward Southern; the other names began as laboratory jargon, but are now accepted terms.
  • These procedures are useful in determining how many copies of a gene are in a given tissue or whether there are any alterations in a gene (deletions, insertions, or rearrangements) because the requisite, initial gel electrophoresis step separates the molecules on the basis of size.
  • Occasionally, if a specific base is changed and a restriction site is altered, these procedures can detect a point mutation.
  • The Northern and Western blot transfer techniques are used to size and quantify specific RNA and protein molecules, respectively. (Option C & D)
  • A fourth technique, the Southwestern or overlay blot, which examines protein-nucleic acid interactions or protein-protein interactions, respectively are variant of the Southern/Northern/Western blotting methods. (Option B)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most powerful technique used in transcription factor research that allows identifying genome-wide DNA binding sites for transcription factors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chromatin immunoprecipitation-sequencing (ChIP-seq) is used for the simultaneous identification of all of the genomic sites bound by a given transcription factor under a given set of physiologic conditions.

Systematic deletion mapping (Option A) is a genetic mapping technique that enables the determination of the location of specific genes on chromosomes.

DNase I sensitivity (Option B) assay is used for discovering regulatory domains. This method maps discrete sites in the genome where the conformation of chromatin renders its DNA hypersensitive to cleavage by the endonuclease DNase I.

Fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH) (Option D) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes that bind to only particular parts of a nucleic acid sequence with a high degree of sequence complementarity.

questions.text: Which of the following can lead to the Denaturation of DNA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The organic solvent formamide, which is commonly used in recombinant DNA experiments, destabilizes hydrogen bonding between bases, thereby lowering the Tm.

  • Formamide addition allows the strands of DNA or DNA-RNA hybrids to be separated at much lower temperatures and minimizes the phosphodiester bond breakage and chemical damage to nucleotides that can occur upon extended incubation at higher temperatures.
  • The double-stranded structure of DNA can be separated into two component strands in solution by increasing the temperature or decreasing the salt concentration. (Option B)
  • Not only do the two stacks of bases pull apart, but the bases themselves unstack while still connected in the polymer by the phosphodiester backbone.
  • DNA can be denatured by increasing the temperature. (Option A)
  • The strands of a given molecule of DNA separate over a temperature range.
  • The midpoint is called the melting temperature, or Tm.
  • The Tm is influenced by the base composition of the DNA and by the salt concentration of the solution.
  • DNA rich in G-C pairs, which has three hydrogen bonds, melts at a higher temperature than DNA rich in A-T pairs, which has two hydrogen bonds.
  • A 10-fold increase in monovalent cation concentration increases the Tm by 16.6°C by neutralising the intrinsic inter-chain repulsion between the highly negatively charged.
  • DNA can be denatured at extreme pH (not at physiological pH around 7.4) (Option D)
